sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method, starting with an initial approximation of x0 = 2, correct to four decimal places.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. The derivative, f'(x), is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2

The Newton-Raphson formula is:

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

We start with an initial approximation of x0 = 2. We will iterate this process until the result converges to four decimal places.

Iteration 1:
x1 = 2 - ( (2^3 - 2*2 - 5) / (3*(2^2) - 2) )
x1 = 2 - ( (8 - 4 - 5) / (12 - 2) )
x1 = 2 - ( -1 / 10 )
x1 = 2 + 0.1
x1 = 2.1

Iteration 2:
x2 = 2.1 - ( (2.1^3 - 2*2.1 - 5) / (3*(2.1^2) - 2) )
x2 ≈ 2.0946

Iteration 3:
x3 = 2.0946 - ( (2.0946^3 - 2*2.0946 - 5) / (3*(2.0946^2) - 2) )
x3 ≈ 2.0950

Iteration 4:
x4 = 2.0950 - ( (2.0950^3 - 2*2.0950 - 5) / (3*(2.0950^2) - 2) )
x4 ≈ 2.0950

Since the result has converged to four decimal places, the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 is approximately x ≈ 2.0950.
